video.title: Full Stack Web App using Vue.js & Express.js: Part 2 - Sequelize
video.description:
Welcome to part 2 of a new series where I will create a full stack web application using Vue.js and Express.js

GitHub repo: https://github.com/codyseibert/tab-tracker

Follow Cody on Twitter: https://twitter.com/CodyLSeibert

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.com

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.com

topLevelComment.author: Kentaro Oka
topLevelComment.text:
From my observation, people are having issues with query at 14:30 not running / Cannot read property 'create' of undefined. 2 things to watch:
1) In your index.js make sure you have .filter(file => file !== "index.js') and not .filter(file => { file !== 'index.js'))
2) Try using const model = require(path.join(__dirname, file))(sequelize, Sequelize) instead of const model = sequelize.import(path.join(__dirname, file))
Another thing you might want to watch:
1) version compatibility of your node and sqlite
2) for message:  "please install sqlite3 package manually", I'd suggesting uninstalling sequalize and sqlite and running:  npm i sequalize sqlite3

replies.author: Gruby
replies.text: @Kentaro Oka You're a Star!

replies.author: Kentaro Oka
replies.text: Another thing to watch is Joi. You must install npm install @hapi/joi as the previous version of Joi has been deprecated. Change the schema and validation to below this: const schema = Joi.object({email: Joi.string().email}, password: Joi.string().pattern(new RegExp('^[a-zA-Z0-9]{8,32}$'))); And for error use const { error } = schema.validate(req.body)

topLevelComment.author: Liefwerk
topLevelComment.text:
If you are an idiot like me and the policy doesn't seem to apply to your request - check that you passed "AuthenticationControllerPolicy.register" before "AuthenticationController.register" in your route.js file.

That took me a few hours to understand that the policy was interacting AFTER the data is sent in JSON to the REST Api. No wonder the policy won't be applied! Now I can relax, until the next error :D

replies.author: Theo Wiik
replies.text:
In index.js (in the server folder).
Change the two lines where he sets the attributs of db to:

db.sequelize = sequelize
db.Sequelize = Sequelize

He forgot to capitalize the last "Sequelize"

topLevelComment.author: Alex Leibowitz
topLevelComment.text: I appreciate your explanations of what you're doing, but even given that you still assume a lot of knowledge about the libraries you are using.  The tutorial would be a better experience for students if you broke down each step into tasks, explained to viewers where they could go to figure out how to complete the task on their own, and then showed the solution.  Just a simple example: when you do the Joi setup, you use a switch statement on the output of Joi's error object to give user feedback.  It would be a better learning experience if their were some way you could encourage students to delve into the error message and documentation for ourselves at this point, rather than just immediately providing the properly structured response.  I guess you could say that a good student should be stopping to figure these things out anyway -- and I don't deny that -- I just mean that you could do more to encourage that kind of follow-through.

topLevelComment.author: Darrell Pawson
topLevelComment.text:
when doing validation I added two things I also allowed certain special characters and I told joi to look for two parts to the domain for the email. With out that someone could register with test@test and it would work.  Now it requires test@test.com or .edu or whatever.  

so here is what my email verification looks like... 
email: Joi.string()
        .email({
          minDomainAtoms: 2
        })

and here is what my password verification looks like...
password: Joi.string()
        .regex(new RegExp(/^[-@./#&+\w\s]{8,30}$/))
        .required()

topLevelComment.author: jy l
topLevelComment.text: I am just wondering what are 'db.sequelize = sequelize' and 'db.sequelize = Sequelize' for?

replies.author: jy l
replies.text: Thanks!

replies.author: Kenneth Horn
replies.text: These add two new items to the db object which is what gets exported. db.sequelize = sequelize attaches the sequelize object we created in the file and db.Sequelize = Sequelize (make sure both have uppercase S, btw) attaches the Sequelize library which we import at the top of the file.

You figure it out? I ran into this too.

replies.author: Tahsin Rashad
replies.text:
Not putting the brace in arrow function means there is an implicit return,
so if you put the braces in the arrow function, you need to explicitly give the return statement.

So either  this

fs
  .readdirSync(__dirname)
  .filter((file) => file !== 'index.js'  )

or this

fs
  .readdirSync(__dirname)
  .filter((file) => {
     return file !== 'index.js'
  })

replies.author: Lihong Han
replies.text: why there should be no brace？

replies.author: Dogemaester
replies.text:
I had the same issue, I found that I was not returning the result of the filter condition. I was doing this:

fs
  .readdirSync(__dirname)
  .filter((file) => {
     file !== 'index.js'
  })

instead of:

fs
  .readdirSync(__dirname)
  .filter((file) => 
     file !== 'index.js'
  )

replies.author: Chriss123
replies.text: having the same issue - Any luck?

topLevelComment.author: AudioBassetHound
topLevelComment.text: At 14:20 if you get a warning saying "sequelize depreciated String based operators are now deprecated. Please use Symbol based operators for better security" just put "operatorsAliases: false" in the options section of your config.js file.

topLevelComment.author: Mr NiceGuy
topLevelComment.text: Great tutorial!!!... I just have a question, what if instead of using vuetify I want to use custom and different css and js external files for every file.vue? does anybody know whats the best approach to achieve this? Thanx!!!

replies.author: Kimberli Smith
replies.text:
To add css to a specific component try the following:
<style scoped>  
your css goes here
</style>
You can put this at the bottom of your file and styling will only apply to the component where the css lives.  Don't think you need external js files, you should be able to put your js inside of <script> tags when you build your "controller".

topLevelComment.author: SlackerKing

topLevelComment.author: Ryan Lindskog
topLevelComment.text: Hey, nice video.  Any reason you're using joi instead of sequelize for validation? Just curious.

replies.author: Darrell Pawson
replies.text: This is my first time using anything SQL based.  I normally use MongoDB and I use Joi's validation along with Mongoose's validation. So if I decide to actually use this app or use it as an example for something else I will definitely use sequelize validation rules as well.

replies.author: John Ludlow
replies.text:
Cody Seibert other tutorials I've seen seem to suggest (and I agree with this) that validation should occur at multiple stages. So you can validate through the database definition, in your controllers, and every step in between.

The reasons I've seen given for this are that a) a client you don't control might connect to your back end but catching errors close to the UI gives better UX and performance, and b) not all types of validating are available at all levels.

topLevelComment.author: Space Wad
topLevelComment.text: everything else is fine but why don't we need any semi-colons here????

replies.author: Kiragu Kimani
replies.text: Since I got into Standard, I don't think I want semi colons anymore

replies.author: Hanuman Singh
replies.text: Read up on Automatic Semicolon Insertion or google JS ASI

replies.author: Abinadi Ayerdis
replies.text: Semicolons are part of the ECMAScript standard. They are required. If you don't put them, they are automatically added. It can cause problems in certain circumstances (admittedly rarely).  Depending on your linting settings, eslint might tell you to add them. Also, many teams require them as part of their coding standards. In my opinion (and only my opinion), there are better reasons to use semicolons than to not use them.

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: I think it's mainly a personal preference.  Imo, the less characters you have to worry about, the easier your code becomes to write and manage.
